706270f-a.text:
Pierrepont Street, at the N.E. corner of Monroe Place, showing the First Unitarian Church of the Saviour. The first services conducted by this church were held in Classical Hall on Washington Street, August 17, 1833. The first pastor was Rev. David H. Barlow, who served until 1838. In 1835 it purchased and moved into the building formerly occupied by the Second Presbyterian Church on Adams Street, (afterwards known as Gothic Hall). The congregation incorporated and became known as the First Unitarian Church of Brooklyn, after the dedication of the present building on April 24, 1844, the present name was adopted. At the left is 50 Monroe Place, and to the right is 121-123 Pierrepont Street.

1922.

Eugene L. Armbruster Collection.
706270f-a.folder: Pierrepont Street & Monroe Place, Brooklyn, NY

706269f-a.text:
(1)
113 Pierrepont Street, at the N.E. corner of Monroe Place, showing
the Unitarian Church of the Saviour.
February 23, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
(2)
The same, from another angle, showing what is probably the chapel of the Church.
March 1, 1929.
P. L. Sperr.
